just started playing a month ago because my 13 year old said i was uncultured swine for never giving rd2 a chance. my advice for early game success would be, find the white arabian, explore and find treasures and special guns to get money fast and uprade guns and camp. pay attention to the 10 challenges as early as possible especially chapter 3. make satchel of the east an early goal. some special treasure are very important and can craft trinkets for upgrades. despite what your jealous 13 year old says, dont sell said special items. gensing exlixer, valerian root and aged pirate rum increase your stats, i didnt know. was just carrying all of it aroun til i figured out they give you boosts. i just started chapter 3 and having a blast just hunting and trying to find rare wild horses atm.

my son bought me a steam deck for christmas this past year. i have maybe 10 hours total on rdr2. it is unlike any other action shooter game i have ever played. the cinematography, characters, and wildlife are so spectacular! i have been reluctant to watch any videos, but there is so much to learn. learning how to navigate the controls controller is a task in itself. you have satchel, supplies, weapon choices, greetings, etc. thanks for the insight. you provided just enough information and tips, without spoiling the storyline.

the van horn mansion glitch still works and it also works with the little cabin at fairyvale shanty...basically loot the location, save the game, reload that save, wash rinse repeat.

another tip that i just discovered last night, you can craft special bullets or arrows while riding your horse. i never knew that but for me it's a game changer as you can just craft small game arrows or split point bullets while you roam towards your preys, four legs or two. i used to stop just to do those while hunting.

for split point rounds, instead of waiting for arthur to bring out a bullet, split, and put it back, you can instead hold x or any relevant button and it will craft it at a much quicker rate, almost 60 split points a minute

one of the things i love about it is how some encounters organically lead into another. case in point ... so i happened up on a deal going down, four men haggling about what appeared to be a stolen wagon. it was night, so i slid over and took a good position behind an old stone wall. the men started arguing, guns were drawn, and in no time at all two of them were dead, one being coldly executed once down with a shot to the head. i figured these were probably not the nicest of men, so decided to take them out. as it happens i had my new winchester rifle that i stole whilst rescuing a store owner's male sex slave, whole different story, and i dropped both scumbags pretty quickly. then i figured there's me, four dead men, and one wagon that's very likely stolen anyway, so hell, i may as well take the wagon and sell it to a fence at emerald ranch. whilst in that neck of the woods and with more cash than i had before, i remembered that marston had a plan to take down a train. for someone who left camp to go hunt a wolf, things really seemed to spiral out of control.

238 in case anyone still doesnt know it yet, you dont need to complete that stagecoach robbery mission in order to unlock the fence. that particular one at emerald ranch will be locked until you complete that mission but other fences will be available to use to buy, craft, and sell things. you can go to rhodes or saint denis to use a fence.

to find the gold bar limpamy is southwest not southeast of horseshoe overlook as he says. it will be north of flatneck station and east if dakota river. it will look like a clump of beige blocks outlined in black on your map. easiest way head all the way west left of horseshoe overlook till you find a river. don't cross it. head south down on the main road that runs along the river thick black line on map. on your left hand side will be a burnt out town, that will be limpamy.

also, for number 4 and help locating it. if you dont find it yourself, javier will have a side mission during chapter 2 where he asks you to go with him. you skip to the homestead instantly and will also get around 125 on top of grabbing the shotgun.

go,and tame the arabian horse as early as you can, its a bit tricky to do but save your game beforehand and you can just try again if it rums away. its free and it has the best stats of any horse in the game, if you bond with it and use it the whole game by chapter 5 or so itll be maxed out. also, buy the best stirrups, they make the horses stamina drain 50 slower.

important tip when you're out in the world, you can fast travel by setting up a campfire. took me a long time to figure that one out, and i was just riding everywhere like a loser.

this is what to do first look up a guide to unlocking the legend of the east satchel it will take a while and a bit of money but it will allow you to hold 99 of most items such as fishing bait and tonics. secondgo to lemoyne and find some gators they give 4 big game meat which fills all cores to the max and you can season them to give golden rings third now that you have the satchel you can hold 99 big game meat and also 99 hay for your horse so now you should always have full cores. fourth unlock the fence and the off hand holster look up treasure map guides and follow them to get a few thousand dollars then get 2 cattleman revolvers as they are the best revolvers in the game once fully upgraded. fifth go to lake isabella and tame the rare white arabian horse it is a great horse early on and very fast but is quite skittish if you dont like it just above big valley there is a small plains once there you will see a fully black through bred it is also a great horse once fully bonded. six enjoy the game hope this helps

first things to do my tips. gather recipes and gather gold ingots and sell. craft recipes and gather plants and herbs. hunt animals that are easy to hunt like deer and pronghorns. find weapons dont rely just on buying weapons. buy hunting spring field rifle and hunt for pelts as well as varmint rifle for small critters. craft enhanced arrows and small game arrows for your bow it will really help when you get hit by larger animals. craft health items and stamina items with dead eye items. hunt pelts to upgrade your satchel and complete challenges to unlock new gear.

there's a working way to get 15,000 off that gold bar in limpony or wherever. recommend saving before trying if you're intent on getting the money, and expect to spend about an hr to get the full 15g all you have to do is pick it up, before you actually put it in your pocket but after it give the little  item pause, save, then immediately load that save. you should then have that gold bar and one in the box still. just repeat until you have thirty of them.

the gold brick is in the southwest of horseshoe overlook! limpany you can see a few houses near the river on the map. you can only sell it in the blackmarket which appears in the main story by time.

it is crazy that so many do not know these and morelike the gold bar at limpany and later braithwaite manor respawn if you close the box. this is also true of large jewelry bags and cash in the abandoned church and at the edge of the swamp near shady hollow, the chest near the split in the train tracks near the north end of the swamp near saint denis. gold nuggets and cash in the abandoned fort, free respawning tomahawks and throwing knives at 6 point cabin, the two gold bars in the fallen rail cars respawn for you as john in the epilogue, and of course that hanging dog and chez porter have respawning cash stacks of 110 and a jewelry bag chez every couple of days. but a ton of things respawn if you close the box or drawers. you can easily have 10 gold bars before you ever unlock the fence by revisiting limpany every time you pass to check. once in the epilogue money is too easy. if you were smart and sold everything and played aberdeen pig farm right before the last arthur mission, and didnt go back for the cash you have about 80100k after buying everything as arthur. go get the respawning shotguns at watsons cabin and chez and then run into horse riders between the two to get a litchfield repeater and schofield, head to fort riggs and take on the skinner ambush and you can get the bow and arrows to complete anything left over as john, without waiting for arthurs weaponsall the while visiting places like lobos camps and rigwood farm for cash, ammo, weapons and unlimited gold ingots without even opening the box with only short rides to the train tracks north to force respawn. money, weapons and gear are the least of your problems in rdr2 or any rockstar game for that matter getting gold medals in 70 missions and guarma compendium animals is far harder than moneygear. that stuff is free. you never need to buy a weapon in rdr2 except for those sold at the fence.

tip once you get to open world in chapter two, horseshoe overlook, you can ride to the fence in st. deniz. it will be open for business, even if you haven't unlocked the fence in emerald ranch. sell your gold bars there.

for anyone new to this video, just in case you didn't know this important detail, i'm about to save you some stress so you're welcome  if you die while having possession of a legendary pelt, it will go straight to the trapper so don't stress that you've lost it! also, legendary pelts can't be damaged unlike 123  animals, so use the most heavy powered gun you have! happy hunting cowpoke

you dont have to wait to unlock the emerald ranch fence to sell or buy things....the rhodes and saint denis fences are already open from the start of ch 2
rdr2  gta5

first things to do is... collect as many plants and herbs as you can for crafting tonics to survive. hunt for meat and animal pelts first. hand in all your hunting pelts to the trapper and camp. explore and find out the new missions you can do. buy weapon hardware. find weapons in the wilderness. start upgrading your camp. buy a hunting rifle and buy express ammo and high capacity ammo for your rifle. your hunting rifle and varmint rifle helps you hunt those pelts. and your bow. craft game hunting arrows for those smaller critters. craft an improved arrow for those larger beasts.
first thing to do is to enjoy the game for ur own experience

on my last mission with arthur, i made the mistake of taking buell, hamish sinclair's old horse, and ive never regretted anything more in a videogame, i was so sad, btw hamish is the veteran in the hunting cabin just east, northeast of valentine and west of beaver hollow

once your in chapter 2. my first thing, get the wreck train goldbars and statue gold bars. take train to rhodes get lancaster from gunsmith and sell gold. the fence in rhodes is already open. unlike emerald ranch. and after u get lancaster empty till. go to fence return to store and go in side door, rob all the ammo. lowers honor but your just starting. so you'll have full ammo for 0. and tons of money from the gold bars. from here it's all you. buy hunting gun or whatever. unlock a few of the 1st challenges one will give you the way to buy an off hand holster immediately long before rescuing micah. so in a few moves your wallet full, your using some of the best guns, your dual wielding. and lastly look for the guy n his jumpy horse. usually it's a thorough bred or better. chase it down and break it in. now you got a quality steed until chapter 4 when you can get arabians. or get the white arabian. i just get the guys horse. much easier and easier travel. now your set. to do all the game challenges like a boss.

love the game i actually wish some of the guns weren't locked in story progression though. just cause i love hunting and messing around just as much or more than actually doing the missions. if it wasn't for trying to unlock a few things like the fishing rod and a couple guns i might have been on chapter 2 for months. that's the sign of a well made game though imo being able to just explore around and have tons of fun doing it cause its so well made.

rdr2 minor assistant game producer here! super glad to hear you enjoyed discovering the sources of each lakes, rivers, and other bodies of water in our game. we actually had around half a dozen hydrologists and geologists on call to assist and basically hold our hand to figure out a way to make this experience as realistic as possible for diehard fans such as yourself! glad to hear you appreciated the hard work, austin.

geologist here! so, the mistaken river feature at 1019, is not actually a mistake, it's something that can happen in real life. bear with me i would love to explain with a diagram but words will need to sufice here . so the bend to the north up in the map is the original course of the river lower montana river. the channel that is in the south down in the map is likely newly formed or artificially dug by humans to aid navigation, but the river doesn't seem deep enough for that. so the original bend may have formed because there was harder material in the way at first, or the river just filled a preexisting depressiongeological feature. but the outer side of the steep bend has more erosive power and so with time it starts eroding any weaker material in the river bank there. with enough time it starts to form a channel that may eventually connect to another part of the river downstream. this would indeed leave the original bent channel as the less efficient option for water to flow as you say. this causes it to have reduced water volume and speed, and the lesser speed makes more material carried by the water to be deposited there. this will eventually cut off that meander a meander is the name of a bent channel in a river, usually in the shape of a half moon from the main water flow and form what we call a meander scar or oxbow lake look it up they look amazing from aerial views. those may even be temporarily filled again during a flood if the water levels raises enough. what you explained will ultimately happen. the issue is it will happen in a geological time scale. it may take 1000 or 10000 years for that meander to be fully abandoned. in a human timescale that's a lot but in a geological one that's the blink of an eye. so you likely encountered the phenomenon in the process of abandoning that northern channelmeander but it just hasn't happened yet. it's not a mistake. if you want to see a similar feature google isla merio, neuqun, neuqun, argentina. you have a bend in a river going north forming an island with the main channel of the river to the south. hope my explanation is understandable. my mother tongue is spanish so i may have some issues translating more technical words into english  edit apparently, the proper term for the abandoned meander in english is meander scar or oxbow lake. i edited that in the explanation.

1115, i'm not a trained hydrologist but i did take some classes in hydrology and others on coastal wetlands. this can and does happen in real life. you see it in coastal river features a lot, like river deltas on meandering rivers. it tends to be a sort of intermediate between when original riversedinemt changes occur and their long term, stable state. essentially, water will always take the path of least resistance, especially a low energy river like a meandering one near where it meets the sea. so if a naturally existing low spot exists there, water will move in to fill it if it can. and while the majority of water would move through the main path, water will also move in to fill the other low spots as well. if there was, say, a canyon through that area, which the surrounding topography on the red dead map kind of implies, the river would fork and flow at a seemingly illogical angle simply because of elevation changes and gravity. i would posit the san jacinto river as it passes through northeast houston as an example of this.

as a geological engineerintraining, an interesting way to study these river systems is with what's called their strahler number. the source streams all start with 1, and when a confluence of another 1 stream occurs the downstream is then designated with a 2, and if two 2 streams meet then downstream it bumps to three. if the 3 stream has a confluence with another 1 or 2 stream however it just absorbs it with no change. so a strahler 4 or 5 river has many sources and as a result is much more influenced by large precipitation or flooding events. based on this video the saint luis river would be a strahler 3, unless the lanahechee was a 3 or higher before flowing into the map from the east. the mississippi river for example has a strahler number of 10, the largest in north america, and the largest in the world is the amazon river at 12.

205 unless, of course, two different people both discovered the rive around the same time, believed it was two different rivers, and the mistake wasn't noticed untill both names had stuck. i am thinking of australia's secondlargest river system, the nepeanhawkesbury river, which runs runs down from the highlands, takes a great big sweep across the plains, disappears back into the blue mountains, and finally pops back out to sea. by the time the mountains were crossed and the river properly mapped, 30 odd years had passed since the river was discovered, and now the upper part is the nepean river, the lower part is the hawkesbury, and there is no particular spot where one name gives way to the other.

regarding dewberry creek, an earlier clue is the meandering path you pointed out that it takes. rapid outflows due to flooding like you hypothesized tend to make wide, straight paths to lower elevation. its an asston of water, rapidly accelerating once any breakthrough is formed its not going to respect the topography of the downhill landscape so much as unmake it. that path, with a clear and curvy band of former riverbed sharply separated from undisturbed plants on either side, that all suggests a longterm and relatively stable river that only recently and perhaps temporarily ceased to be. man, i used way fancier words to say that than i meant to

1835 it's not eroding the bank due to the water is moving faster on the turn, it's because the water is physically impacting it. the turn is a consequence of the water hitting the bank and deflecting, eroding a little in the process, which starts a feedback loop, because the steeper angle makes the water hit harder, and the curve become more and more dramatic until the lobes of an s meet and pinch off leaving a scaroxbow

you should absolutely buy rdr 2 no matter what year it is. i have been playing it for about two years now and am 97 through. i have finished the story but still have stuff to find south of blackwater. i was in no rush to complete this game and have had breaks over the last two years. i wanted it to last as long as possible as it will be years before rdr 3 comes out. i have tried to do everything there is to do and find all the collectables which i am proud to say i have nearly achieved without the use of any guides or googling. i have put around 2000 hours in to the game so far and from the start i have been using the ingame camera to capture glorious images of the world and many action scenes along with all the missions. i have nearly 9,000 images so far and plan to put them in a video when i complete the game with music from the rdr 2 album playing throughout the video. my current guess if i display each image for 4 seconds with a fade in and out means the end video will be around 16 hours long which i will have to split in two videos due to youtubes upload limit of 12 hours. i am guessing nobody has made a video like this of rdr 2 so it will be my tribute to what is in my opinion the greatest video game ever made. i hope to finish the game and have the two videos made and uploaded sometime in 2025 so keep an eye on my channel if that's something you'd enjoy watching.

i love the animals in this game. the pronghorn outrun your horse fastest land mammal over long distances, the opossums play dead so you can't study them since they're 'not alive', brown bears attack whilst black bears run away, the carolina parakeets are almost extinct around the same time as in real life, woodpeckers actually sick on the trees and go ham. just so detailed and accurate. there's a few other animals i would have liked to see like porcupine, black footed ferrets, fishers to name a few but overall this game satiates the animal enjoyer in me that's been growing since i was able to read books.

what's great about red dead is that, while gta is a vulgar satire of contemporary american culture that honestly gets a little old, red dead especially 2 has a deep, mature appreciation of its setting. the landscape, the animals are brought to live in a realistic seeming way. the soundtrack is an incredible evocation of american folk music forms. there is so much to experience in this game just observing and taking in the environment. while gta wrings a laugh out an annoying npc being kicked in the head, red dead invites you to listen and watch as moose takes a drink in a stream. or in reading arthur's journal and seeing his drawings and his appreciation of the things he you sees in the world. the frontier spirit is well captured not in dutch's gang, but in all the civilians they come across. the dramatic irony of the game which arthur comes to realize as the plot progresses is that most of the people the gang encounters and usually robs are just trying to make a living in a difficult environment and that the gang, while itself being a sort of family, is an antisocial force in this environment. this is by far the best game i've ever played in my 38 years of life.

when i was 11 years old i used to watch my brother in 2013 play gta 5 on his ps3 and he would do live commentary specifically for me to follow along and understand what he's doing, he would never place a marker for any destination on the map. he knew where he was going and how to get there, which streets to turn left or right on, he would pass by a lamp post and tell me a funny moment that happened to him there. i would sit and watch as he got to were he needed to be without needing a marker in amazement. every single game i ever played i would always try to get to the same familiarity that he had with that map but i never could, until rdr2 came out. the train tracks you could follow to valentine, the valley between the heartlands and flatneck station, the train tracks you could follow from annesburg, to van horn, all the way to saint denis. i didn't need to place a marker on the map to know where i'm going, i just went there. i could get lost in the woods near emerald ranch and find my way back to saint denis just by finding a road. they did such an amazing job with adding little details to the environment that i could know where i was by using them as markers. rdr2 will hold a special place in my heart not just for it's amazing story telling and atmosphere, but for helping me connect to my brother and feel as if ive finally reached him even after his passing.

i've always thought rdr2 would stand the test of time and be viewed alongside the great works of art from the 20th century. it's a masterpiece in every sense of the word in a way i think no other video game before or since has ever matched. it's been 6 years and we still haven't gotten close to matching rdr2's graphics. its writing is so deep and complex that it draws comparison to the greatest prestige tv shows of all time like deadwood or the wire. it's phenomenally immersive and makes you genuinely feel like you're in the world. and on top of all that  it's a good fucking game. fun to play and infinitely replayable. sad to think we probably won't get another game like this ever again since the housers left rockstar.

i stopped playing for a long period of time shortly after arthur became ill, something about it just wasn't clicking with me. then i decided to get back into it after my wife brought it up in conversation. i replayed some of the ealier missions to get caught up on the story since i largely forgot what happened. it was when arthur went to round up dept money was the moment i realized the reason why arthur got sick later on in the game, it was because he contracted tuberculosis from thomas downes man he assaulted to get dept money. the reason why arthur got sick was because his loyalty to dutch became a sickness, both literally and spiritually. arthur got sick because he allowed dutch to corrupt his integrity. in order to redeem himself, arthur gives john a future that he never allowed himself to have, even if it was a fleeting moment. realizing that was the moment i decided this game was special. it's not a game you can rush, you have to sit with it to understand the story the game wants to tell. the way the game threads together it's story and themes is masterful. i have never seen a game accomplish it so well.

you can increase the bond with your horse by leading it by the reins for a bit. petting a horse immadiently after a fullstop or in situations where it made a good job  jumping over a fence, staying calm in dangerous situations etc increases the bond also. some doors are locked but sometimes you can enter a cabin by breaking the windows. traveling with a second horse allows you to carry more hunted animals around. the first thing you wanna do after getting the leather tools is to let pearson craft the satchels for you. the camp in valentine lets you eat out of the pot similar to that of your camp. nobody stops you from doing it. burningdynamite, molotow etc people impedes looting them. you can shoot fish with guns or the bow. if you can't craft anything but seemingly have the recipe you may consider reading it to learn it. i forgot it once and i really almost lost my sanity because of this if you're stuck somewhere high where you'd fall and die, just set up a camp.

i have 100 the story, as well as the game, and never knew you could stay and apologize to a lawman. you can speed up and slow down, as well as change camera view while in cinematic view. to speed up the process on cigarette cards, go to the general store and buy as many as possible, then get rid of them, buy more, and repeat. it took me about 10 minutes and about 620 to get all the cards. you can feed and brush your horse while riding. you can feed them at any speed, but to brush them, it must be at a slow trot. if you greet and npc in a town with the law, and that npc makes a rude remark, antagonize him until he starts to shoot you, the lawman will shoot and kill him for you. to maintain weight, eat 3 meals then sleep. that will bring up your weight by 0.75. if you eat 3 candies or chocolates along with the 3 meals, it will bring up your weight by 0.75, but also continue to bring up your weight again over the next day or so. i find it best to maintain 0.75 to 3.00 for best results. it is very hard to maintain a perfect body weight unless you literally eat a meal every 8 hours, or 3 meals every 24 hours. certain npcs that need help along side the ride, example guy who was bit by a snake, or guy caught in bear trap, will get you one free item from the gunsmith or general store in the town he was closest to. i think there is one guy per town that you can help, i found 5 of them. snake bite guy 3 different times.

if you antagonize an npc in town that has a gun then slowly pull in the right trigger, they'll reach for their gun and you can duel them.

if you have bought the fast travel upgrade at your camp, you can fast travel from anywhere by setting up a campfire and pressing ax. it even allows you to fast travel back to your main camp.

if your horse is stuck mountain, trees, just make a camp and your horse will go to your camp.

you can increase your bond with your horse if you reassure it talk to it after it's had a bad experience  like if you ride it through tall bushes or it gets spooked by predators. basically in any situations where the horse either acts skittish or makes a little sound of distress not the heavy breathing from hard riding, if you press the button to talk to it arthur will say things like 'sorry, girl', or 'you're alright girl'.

if you just set the prisoner free you meet him again a few times and you can get more robbery tips
i suggest checking all fireplaces more than once when you first search them. some have multiple items. even destroyed houses with a fire place still standing can have loot in it.

i was riding near camp in ch2 and a guy got bit and asked me to suck the poison out, i helped him bc i am working towards high honor. the line arthur says afterwards cracked me up. i completely forgot about the guy and now im about halfway done with the story. i returned to valentine and the guy called out to me by the gunsmith and bought me a free gun since i saved his life. it was so great! an awesome surprise.
if you're up on a mountain top or a precarious ledge and getting down is kinda iffy.....set up camp.

extra tip going in and out of dead eye every time you shoot someone instead of shooting multiple at once will actually drain less dead eye energy and your weapons automatically reload each time. second extra tip if you ever find youself in a rush through a tight forest, just let go of the controlls and the horse will automatically dodge all the trees. really wide rocks and trees will still send you flying though.
if you find the prisoner and free him successfully, he might recognize you later and gift you any gun from the shop on his tab. i ran into him in valentine and got a 150 pistol out of it

two huge tips, get the legendary satchel as soon as you can, it has space for 99 of most items and you can get all the pelts since the second episode. also you can know the quality of a pelt by studying and then pointing at the animals, three stars is perfect pelt, then just use the right weapon.
tips that actually help, not drawing out the time of the video, everything to the point. awesome. thank you!

take your main horse and two other horses in your stable when going hunting to carry more carcass's to consolidate your trips and save time and make more money. just have your two spare horses follow your main horse.

another tip! you can actually hunt with your lasso! particularly hoofed animals like deers, goats, elk, even bison, but do be warned, it depletes your stamina quickly so always use a potent stamina tonic before doing so and try get close enough to the animal when on your horse this can be used to instantly kill high quality animals without damaging the meatpelt do not try it on predators

excellent video!!! the editing, explanations, clarity... everything. you really did a great job. my tip if you want to commit crime, then learn how the witness system works, as well as disguises... 1. lawmen always know your id 2. dark red witnesses on the minimap don't know your id, but are still reporting your crime. 3. bright red witnesses know your id, and are reporting you directly.
use express ammo in your pistolsrevolvers. it's a huge upgrade to damage during gunfights, even when you don't have access to your long guns, and also really helps when you have no dead eye.

i never saw anyone ever mentioning this, but i think that you can whether your horse is hungry by watching whether its pawing at the ground when you give it some food. after 34 treats, the horse will stop pawing. pawing is how grazing animals dig up snow to reveal vegetation during wintertime, so it might be indicating that the horse is still hungry.

the multiple outfits part yeah you can switch between outfits from your horse which is convenient, just don't take offput on a hat because that will count as a separate custom outfit and will remove another one from your horse. but of course it never replaces the outfit that is exactly the same minusplus the hat, it's always one of the completely different outfits so you have 2 of the same thing with and without a hat oh and if you're wearing a hat and it falls off and you want it back on, other than picking it up off the ground put the custom outfit on again, don't select the same exact hat from your horse because then you'll be there like where did that other outfit go and why do i have two of the same on my horse listed as two different outfits? it's immersive

people dont know how excited i was for rdr2 bc i loved rdr1 vut i realized alot of people had never played it. i didn't even know anything about it. i just went to blockbuster 1 day browsing  a guy saw me reqading the back of the game  he told me i should get it, its really good. its like gta in the western days. it has been in my top 3 games since. i dont usually replay games but ive replayed rdr1 so many times over the years. i remember them saying there wasnt goin to be another rdr. i always felt like the true ending of rdr1 shouldve been a game bc i spent aloooot of time playing as jack as an adult being a bounty hunter after i had gotten revenge for john marston. i used to leave the house  head to blackwater early in the morning and wait at the train station until the police comes and nails up the bounty. i would do maybe 3 bounties a day until it started getting dark and i would go back to the house and sleep and wake up the next day and do it again lol. sometimes i used to go to mexico and do bounties there for a little while when i wanted a change in scenery

honestly, before anyone judges me for this trust me, read the whole comment i really like horse games as someone who rides horses in real life and i like looking for realistic details in horse games. i am aware that this game is not specifically a horse game but the fact that there are so many realistic elements to the horses, behaviour and animations is amazing to me. i really like that you have to actually care for the horse in order to maintain their health and stamina. i really like how the horses will spook when they come across predators i like how sometimes even when you fire your gun in the game the horse will spook depending on the horse that you have. i have some horses that will completely stop running if i fire a gun and spook a little bit and i have another horse that will just keep running and doesnt even care when i fire the gun. so, even though i started originally playing this game as i kinda just played it in a free mode version, and it just rode around and caught wild horses and teamed them, and sold them that kind of thing and i did like a little bit of hunting now im actually getting into playing the story mode of the game but like i said, there are so many realistic details to the horses like the fact that if you leave them in water and get off them, theyll get out of the water the fact that they will have steam cum off them if you come from a cold area to a hot area or it might be vice versa im not sure the fact that when it rains you can see your horses coat visibly get wet when you ride through muddy areas your horse visibly gets dirty. all of these things are so realistic but theres such small details i just really like that they put into it and it even though im not. just playing the game for the horse mechanics anymore like i was i still very much i do appreciate them and there are times where i just played free mode and ill just go and tame a bunch of wild horses and sell them or ill just ride around on my horse and do you like trail rides around the area because i do really like the graphics of the game as well. all in all the behaviour for the horses in the second game is just a lot better compared to the first one from what i can see in this one, and i absolutely love the behaviors, the graphics the details that they add to the horses is just perfect.

the storytelling in gta has often taken a backseataside from the standout example of gta ivto focus on immersing players in a sandbox filled with endless possibilities. the emphasis is more on how much chaos you can unleash, with missions serving as a secondary layer of engagement. rdr is all about the narrative. its primary goal is to channel the atmosphere of classic western films, placing you in a very detailed open world that prioritizes storytelling and immersion. i find myself engaging with these two game series in completely different ways. in gta, i try to cause as much mayhem as possibleblowing up cars and orchestrating massive shootouts, testing how long i can outlast the police. on the other hand, rdr inspires a more thoughtful, roleplaying approach. i tend to imagine how john or arthur would live their lives, allowing me to slip into their shoes and approach the game with a more characterdriven playstyle.

playing rdr2 again and enjoying it. bought a 32 inch screen for the immersion. the best part of the game is that it seems real. no spells or magic or leaping off buildings or soaring through the air or zombies or other monsters. just real people making good and bad decisions and living with the consequences. heightened real life. nice. thank you rockstar.

its sad as hell when you give abigail that kiss and she says to tend to the farm, youve already done every bounty and side mission, got your fill of hunting and fishing and you just know the ride is over, and you saw all you came to see. i got that same sad feeling when you wake up in kaer morhen and everybody is gone, no more friends to do quests with, no more storyline, its over. its the biggest compliment i can give to any game if i get that feeling at the end of it.

i totally get the hype for gta 6, but honestly, i'm craving a red dead redemption 3 sequel even more. there's this magic to exploring the wild west of the 1800s  the calmness, the way nature takes its time, and soaking in every inch of the landscape that makes you appreciate the game even more. sometimes, i wish i could actually live in the 1800s, and playing rdr2 feels like the closest i'll get to that experience.

i used to have 3 save files on rdr2 1. for me to try to get completion 2. when my stepdad and i hung out 3. when i would hang out with my dad. had to do high honor with my stepdad around, because i didnt want him to see what i was capable of  with my dad we would be sore from laughter when we would throw people on train tracks or try and get away with as much as possible, but i didnt spoil arthurs ending for him at all playing it. when arthur got his diagnosis he was all in on redeeming him and it made playing through that part of the game easier and more memorable since he honestly even cared about arthur in the game. i think that kind of speaks volumes to how wide of an audience it is accessible to, and the success of its writing being a really emotionally complex and engaging piece of fiction. for both my stepdad and my dad to want to just be there with me playing it and connecting between both was a positive thing for me.

dont forget the music. the music makes it 10x more immersive. or should i say the sound ambience in general. when you just ride along to some peaceful guitar music and animal noises, enjoying the view, then suddenly it changes to some dark uncanny sound while you hear multiple horse riders from afar getting louder and louder, realizing that bounty hunters are coming for your head. this is so good man
1658 hours and i still love this game. for me nothing even compares to it and i still play it almost daily. great video, thanks for doing this.

this is my personal favorite piece of art of all time. arthur morgan might just be my favorite character in all of fiction. and i will never be embarrassed to say that. rockstar delivered a video game so immersive and so powerful and so incredible that i don't think they could ever artistically top it.

picked it up cheap recently, and i've got about 50 hours in the game now. but i'm not really playing rdr2  i'm playing a rpg with a guy named arthur as the hero. i actively avoid the story missions  anything to do with micah ends in slaughter of innocent people, and that's not what my arthur is all about. got my honour up to touching distance of the right edge of the bar! i'm the robin hood of the wild west! next story mission is stealing some oil carriages with john marston. i didn't play the first game, but apparently he was the hero, so i'm hoping he is a bit more sensible than micah. got a hell of a lot of exploring to do first  at the moment i'm riding the whole perimeter of the map, seeing what is to be seen. it is beautiful  coming down from the mountains in the early morning, into an autumnal forest, with the god rays all around. wonderful.

im doing a second playthrough six years later and im only on chapter 2. keep getting sidetracked by exploring, hunting, random events and just watching that world go by. at this rate its going to take me months to finish it again. love it, so much fun!

candidly, playing through this recently for the first time i caught myself multiple times just being in the moment and actually feeling grateful and fortunate to play this game. its such a rare feeling that i almost never felt playing a game.

not playing rdr1 and not knowing that dutch is the villain on the game, that scene at 858 completely broke my heart. i though somehow, someway dutch loves arthur and no matter their difference in opinions is, theyll still have each other's back down the line. but that scene right there completely shattered on whats left on my loyalty to dutch. the same way arthur did at that moment.

i started a new game recently and am currently playing through it now. this is my first time playing it sober, and i have to say, wow. it's probably as close as one can get to playing a game over for the first time because i was so blitzed out of my mind years ago, my memory of the game is fragmented at best. playing it sober, my appreciation for this game, and the work put into it, has skyrocketed. i've played a whole lot of games over the decades, and i daresay this is my absolute favorite.

it blew my mind and still does. think about it, hundreds of people working on this for years and years. the endless hours of work poured into it. and we end up with a masterpiece. loved every minute of it.

the game is so insanely well made. never seen this level of detail in any game ever before i was in a shack in the middle of nowhere where i found an axe. and i took the axe and threw it against the wall it made a wood sound. i took the axe again and threw it against a picture it made a paper rip sound. i took it again and threw it against a horse saddle nearby it made a sound leather rip sound. i took it again and threw it against a rope it made a rope rip sound.

replaying this currently for the second time since release, and it's even better than my first playthrough. the more i play, the more i think rdr2 got absolutely robbed that year by god of war... this game is as close to a masterpiece as possible. there is no game more visually beautiful than rdr2, i cannot believe this released on lastgen. it takes my breath away every single time i play it. almost every aspect of this game is an absolute triumph.

you didn't even touch on the soundtrack. i was already enjoying it, but when i got on a horse after returning from guarma  not knowing what i was going to find left of the gang  and unshaken started playing it hit hard. i knew in that moment this was no ordinary video game and i would be forever changed by it. i d'angelo's performance was just haunting, and i recognized daniel lanois' production immediately. he did bob dylan's album time out of mind, among many others it all fit in so nicely with woody jackson's score. then the part that broke me is losing my horse at the end. why, rockstar, why?!

rdr2, in my opinion, has some of the best technical aspects in a game. i cant think of any other game with such a high amount of detail in everything. story, world, physics and all the other aspects of a game. that being said i kind of wish that there were more fun missions that would have been fully open ended because it is a open world game. that would have been the cherry on top for me.

in my opinion, this is a world class novel that was then adapted into a video game if you know what i mean. i m in my 40s and both me and my wife could not stop playing it until we got 100 completion. and at the core of it was the emotional and historical depth it carries but as well the actors' performances. i bet that 90 percent of those who played this game had tears in their eyes when that end hits. if there are any tool fans here, i would say red dead redemption 2 is tool of video games.

great video for an absolute masterpiece of a game. this is what you get when the time is taken to bring all elements of a game together. too many games today focus on only a couple of things and then release a buggy mess. this game is was and always will be a masterpiece. thanks for taking the time to put this video together. going to go and start yet another play though.

this game is still a top three. going back to it is like going on vacation, its so beautiful. the slow, steadiness of it is like meditation. truly one of the greatest experiences in gaming ive ever had. maybe ill go back for a fifth playthrough.

out of the dozens and dozens of hours i spent on my first playthrough, my forever favorite part of this game is the camp party after you rescue sean. it was such a surprising step back from the madness going on that everyone just took a night to drink and laugh and dance and sing around the fire. it was such a beautifully wholesome moment and only doubled down my love for this game. i guess because it reminds me of growing up, we always have field parties with a fire and singing. it just made the crew that much more relatable for me

i got the low honor ending on my first play through. i was so pissed that i stopped playing and didn't touch the game for 3 days because i needed to cool down. when i did play it again i started over from the beginning to get the high honor ending. i'm not ashamed to admit that i cried. i used to be ashamed i was like why the hell am i crying about a video game character?. then i saw a few compilation videos of other people crying at the end so i didn't feel bad anymore. the epilogue was all new to me since i never played it on my first play through. i like video games, but i'm far from being considered a gamer. this is still the best game i've ever played in my life.

having just beaten the game, guarma didn't bother me nearly as much as i expected it to from this video. my main complaint was all the handholding rockstar does during missions. you are constantly given text instructions, even for things you've done dozens of times. rarely can you stray from the intended path, and if you aren't doing what the game wants for literally two seconds an ai starts loudly berating you for it. otherwise i thought it was an amazing experience that sets the bar very high for sequels. it not only improved on the first game in pretty much every aspect, it expanded the world and story, making the original game even better for it.

i think i understand dunkey's argument about the story, even if i disagree. the tone shifts drastically, so if you really got into the light hearted first half it might throw you off. personally i think it's masterful how as arthur's journey becomes darker and more introspective, the entire game pulls you into it. you could even argue the straightforward shootouts in the latter half drive home how tired and disillusioned arthur becomes. the best parts of the final chapters are the intimate stories and experiences, which helps drive home how narratively these become more important to arthur than ever.

the carolina parakeet is extinct and has been for over 100 years. nice touch to have the game take place within the same few years that the parakeet went extinct in real life.

wearing the expert hunter outfit, killing buffalo to get double materials. then putting on the savvy merchant outfit and traveling to mexico to sell the pelts for 5x what theyre worth in west elizabeth was the way to get stacked on rdr1.
as a native north carolinian i wish the carolina parakeet wasnt extinct cause it would be so cool to see these colorful birds fill the sky

fun fact their own defense mechanism accelerated their own extinction. in the early 1910s, southern farmers were very protective of their crops from which the parakeet would eat on. so they would shoot them with their shotguns and when one parakeet would get injured the entire flock of parakeets would come try and swarm the injured bird to protect them. unfortunately, grouping up against a remington model 10 doesnt help as much as an animal.

its a reference to how a lotnof buffallos were killed in the early us, almost making them extinct
manifest destiny is a quote from the us government in the 1800s when settlers went west in search of land and gold, designed to inspire settlers against the natives, depicted as a spirit essentially

the manifest destiny achievement is supposed to reference how american settlers did every attempt to kill off as many buffalo as they could to starve native american tribes buffalo was their main food source, and force them into submission during westward expansion. this would explain probably why some of the buffalo in rdr1 doesnt respawn again, due to how many killed buffalo there was. besides that reason, hunting buffalo was also a popular sport for settlers at the time.

fun fact manifest destiny was the term used by early american colonists which said that it was their divine right to plunder the land and hunt the wildlife, which is a very fitting for the achievement
it is likely called manifest destony as there was an effort by colonists to wipe out the natoves by taking away their percieved primary food sourse

man i remember when rdr2 came out back in 2018 right around my birthday. thats all i played for a few months. but now after over 6 years i redownload this masterpiece so i can start on a 2nd play through. ive played many of games since rdr2 and i got to say arthur morgan is still one of if not the greatest main protagonist ive ever had the pleasure of playing as. i havent felt invested into a character like him since. cant wait to play this again and relive what made this one of the greatest gaming experiences ever.

im playing the game again for probably the tenth time and this time im doing it different. ive decided to play it slow and really enjoy how beautiful the game is. i dont play background music, i dont run around everywhere in a hurry, i eat and drink in a common manner, and make choices that i can truly see myself making. so far it is the most relaxing play through ive had and im really enjoying it.

i have been an avid gamer since 1980 when i got an atari 2600 for christmas, and over the years i've played countless games on just about every console made. rdr 2 is by far the most immersive and detailed game i've ever played. im on my 6th playthrough on story mode and am level 130 online. its the only game i've played for the last 2 years. all other games now just pale by comparison. i might need some red dead rehab..lol

rdr2 taught me you cant rush with some games. the level of attention to detail is immense, and you are absolutely going to miss some of it. ive been playing the game with low honor and its insane how much the world is warped by your actions. fantastic experience that i doubt ill be able to get anywhere else until gta vi

currently in chapter 3 of my 9th playthrough and im full immersive mode. not only is my minimap turned off, but im not allowed to use the map at all. going strictly off things like the sunstreet signsetc for navigation, use my pocket watch to tell the time, have a regular sleep schedule, huntcook all my food and eat every day, change my clothes every day, bathe, not getting any of the hidden treasures, walk everywhere, lead my horse during travel sometimes to give it a break, never fast travel.. its taking me forever to progress through the story but its so much fun and would highly recommend

one thing i like to do is hitchhike, i put my horse away safely in the stables and just go see if i can hitch a ride on a stagecoach. another thing you can do is sneak on trains and ride them to the next destination, if the train guards don't see you then no bounty will be placed and the train will operate like normal.

all the good things said about this game reflect my sentiments. i recently discovered a way to do that which the game forbids  completely free roam in chapter 1. yes, you heard me  in chapter 1 immediately after the second mission. it all starts with a trip to the shack at cairns lake and afterwards heading to deadboot creek to get the carbine repeater from the jeremiah johnson frozen man west of that creek. what a game.

red dead 2 is the embodiment of the best of each department bringing their best work forward. it's so fun to just sit there as a game developer and think about the countless hours, hard work, and passion the devs poured in, in every single possible defining way. the sounds are all beautifully crafted and handled, the open world is gorgeous and densely populated, the performances are just, voila, delissimo. even the programming for something even as simple as a scenario somewhere in the world is insanely complex and reactive it's insane and it raises the bar extraordinarily high for future rockstar titles. i can only imagine the programmers had their own fun crafting the systems and engine, and the rest of the team had a whole other kind of fun filling everything in with the story, cool easter eggs, funny encounters, etc. it's just so awesome. i love good games. we need more of em. p.s. i rock the lote outfit and exotic hat, such a nice combo bruh

mods have kept this game alive for me. i never got into online because once i changed some of the gameplay aspects, there was no going back. my list contains the following clean horse less dirty over time no auto horse equipping  holstering weapon rebalance realistic navigation w hidden mini map online content unlocker  why ems dlc no bullet trails cinematic ped accuracy remove screen effects micahs hair fix hunting rebalance holstering animations no hitmarkers realistic loadouts for npcs serving spoon fix spoon bug fix maize sack fix ped damage overhaul softercores fix toggle run first person walk default more persistent weather camp anywhere all weapons unlocked in catalog longer days my 24 hour in game clock is tweaked to last 8 hours in real time. nice long sunrises and sunsets and plenty of time to enjoy the world and not have the days fly by rdr2 is my favorite game ever. hope my post helps people if they want to find some more immersive mods.

when i play this game it gives me a feeling that nothing else has ever given me. the last of us 1  2 are the closest thing to give me the same feeling but its still not the same exact feeling. red dead redemption 2 gives me this warm and happy feeling when i play. like you said, its so immersive that you cant help but play the game as if you are really in it. the open world is so beautiful especially when in the wild, on some mountains looking around. the story line is absolutely amazing, and hunting is also amazing. the world is huge and you come across something new all the time. its actually really sad that rock star hasnt made any dlcs for the game. i mean i know so much work , time, and money went into making this beautiful game. and for them to just not create new storylines for us to play is just so frustrating to me. but with that all said, this game is thee best most beautiful game i have ever played and nothing else can give me the same exact feeling. no nostalgic movie or cartoon, no real world place, no item that reminds me of childhood. such an amazing experience its kind of hard to put into words!

started fresh new playthrough after moving on from xbox to pc this game is by far the greatest story ive ever experienced. playing it at steady 70 to 60fps feels so brand new better graphics than xbox one x 30fps at the time was the norm and had no issues but experiencing this at unlocked fps just feels like a whole new experience. its been 7 years and it feels like a movie that you havent seen in such a long time im picking up dialog mainly memorable ones but my goodness the acting and writing in this game is top tier ive yet to see a beautiful open world like red dead redemption 2. i missed out on big game hunting and handful of random side quests and world encounters mainly focused on main story line with some quests. it saddens me how the state of modern gaming is at the moment with insert identity politics gender politics this game is clearly made by passionate developers and i pray to god that gta 6 feels alive and full of detail. still cant get over how they killed rdonline and how they could have ported rdr1 remade on the new engine that would have made so much money for them  rdr1 pc is ready to after this game to have that total experience.

john not being able to swim makes the epilogue so much more painful, especially if you're going for 100.
arthurs dead eye makes make players feel nervous
i always interpreted the deadeye as to highlight that john is so concentrated on his target that he can hear his heartbeat, and arthur is concentrated on the time it takes to shoot his target.

john starts drowning the moment he jumps into water, probably because he cant swim. i love how he says, probably, as if it could also be some other reason, like john just ate a big meal or had lead in his boots or something.
also, when you're playing as john, the death screen looks like the one in rdr1.
it all makes sense when you think of the theory that john list sight in his left eye after the wolf attack.
the only time john puts effort into the journal is when he draws arthurs grave

the ticking clock is arthur coming closer and closer to his end and the end of the life he knew the wild west as he remarks often throughout the game, while johns is the heartbeat representing the life he currently has and wants to hold on to, to go home alive to. pretty poetic ngl and a great subtle choice
i will always prefer arthurs deadeye sound. john sounds like hes focusing in on the enemy, arthur sounds like hes focusing on making his time count.

i remember hearing that the ticking from arthers dead eye symbolized his focus and johns heart beating was his nerves getting to him. i like the other ideas of what it could mean

i like to think that john's deadeye having heartbeats is just as simple as him being more adrenaline driven while arthur is just a more efficient with his time and cold thinking when he needs to shoot something, which adds a lot to them as characters. art is art, everyone may interpret it differently

it would have been cool if the ticking sound came in at chapter 2 when he gets tb, and gets progressively louder in every chapter until it's really bothering and then finally goes silent in the final shootout. i think that would be pretty good foreshadowing.

1. the john's deadeye sound is the same sound from the first game. thought that was a nice touch. 2. john cant swim because in the first game you would instantly drown in water. it became an inside joke in the second game and i love how the devs made it a part of his character. 3. john wont be as fast as arthur until he meets landon ricketts, who helps him improve his quickdraw. so i love how they made hin slower than arthur.
john is actually partially blind in his left eye from the wolf attack so thats why he closes it
oh, so thats why john instantly dies when he falls on water on rdr1

i actually like that every single gameplay element has arthur better than john. fits the story. john isnt that character from rdr yet. arthur is looking out for him, almost as a big brother. john still has to grow into that fearless gunslinger that we love.
the irony on john and arthurs deadeye sfx. arthur time is coming up, johns heartbeat of last breath.
arthur keeping both eyes open is a great detail to support that hes a better shot than john. a detail that id be surprised to learn was by design for that reason
i feel like the reason arthur's deadeye is ticking because he doesn't have much time

johns deadeye is a heartbeat, signifying his family and why he does everything that he does. whilst arthurs is a ticking clock, which represents his limited time to live during the events of the story.

i think it's worth pointing out that the two eyed vs one eyed aim is more indicative of combat styles. both eyes opened are best for close quarters shooting so you have a wider field of view. where having one eye closed it more for precision shooting and long distances.

i've been playing rdr2 on  off since 2018  i'm still finding things i didn't know about. slowly going for all mission golds this, my 3rd complete play through. enjoy, my friends, best story  best acted game i've ever encountered to date. i've been playing the franchise since 2005 starting with red dead revolver, and between phil  fizhy i've not only learned a tremendous amount about all the depth in this game  all the historical connections plus all the western film references in this great story, but also enjoyed a ton of fun  humorous content from these two fantastic presenters . i grew up a duster fan, wanted dead or alive, the rifleman, paladin etc. on tv  all the western movies from the 50's to the present, stagecoach, rio bravo, both 310 to yuma's, the unforgiven, all the eastwood westerns,  open range amongst my favorites, this game allowed me to live in all those films. a gamer's dream come true, i'll still be playin' this game on my deathbed.

first game to make me cry. started playing after an arrest and decided to quit being a party girl and stay in focus on myself and used my free time playing on a playstation given to me by my sister law. i had never heard of red dead before. only gta. figured since i liked gta this game would be a fun little adventure nothing to exciting. i had to stop playing the game for a few months after reaching a certain part and i knew what was about to happen. ive made so many life long friends from the online community. this game literally changed the course of my life. arthur is just a video game character. but that character kept me wanting to stay away from my former behaviors. he isnt real but the way i became so invested into his journey became real to me. rock star has been greedy and making choices that the community absolutely hates. but because of something they made im a different better person. arthur was real to me. this game is so great. not perfect. but ill forever have so much love for a character that i thought was going to be a forgettable little side hobby. if anyone reads this. and especially if youre playing for the first time. stop watching any videos about it. focus on the game. go through the first play through blind if at all possible at this point. explore. help strangers. trust me when i say first play through. youll know after the game youll play it all over again. enjoy.
15 hours in. this game is something extrodinary ngl

tips 1. sometimes you will find animal carcasses on pearson's table. you can skin it and donate it back to pearson for easy resource. 2. you can pull a dead body from the driver seat of a caravan with your lasso. the same can be done to some of the dead animals that are in water bodies.

this game just went on sale for a historical low on epic, experiencing it for the first time. dodged all youtuber playthroughs because i wanted to experience it myself. i'm at around 50 progress now and i'm glad i've been so thorough, knew most of the tips already. i never knew you could duel with just about anyone and also i had no idea the hats or clothing items you collected went in your inventory permanently. thanks!

tips 1. you can pat your horse from time to time while riding it to restore some of its stamina. 2. snake carcass rot slowly if at all. 3. you can fish using small game arrows for perfect fishes. 4. you can steer fishes in shallow water towards land and they will die and will be ready for pickup although icons won't appear in the minimap. 5. you cannot saddle up the white arabian if you haven't completed the 1st hosea mission. 6. take a temporary horse which has a saddle bag so that you can carry more small carcasses. 7. you can bring most criminals to a police station for a reward. but don't have himher long on your horse or they might die. 8. remember if unskinned carcasses rot you lose all the resources from it. skins and meat after butchering will never rot. 9. black bears will run from you but grizzles mostly don't. 10. you can lasso a bison but can't kill it with a knife. 11. you can lasso most charging animals who can be lassoed. 12. you can bring lassoed enemies and dead bodies from river towards you with the fire button.

just started this game 2 weeks ago, almost at 50 now and my mind still blown away by all the details in it. i am not sure if that could count as a tip but leading your horse create bonding. i was in lvl 23, led my horse for around 1015 min and we became lvl 4 bonding. i was pretty surprised!

you get a hungarian halfbreed for free in chapter 2. if you accept the first wanted poster, leave your horse on the slope and walk to albright. arthur automatically takes albright's horse for his pursuit. deliver the prisoner to the sheriff, ride back, whistle for your horse, and ride both horses to the stables in valentine. the hungarian halfbreed is perfect for fighting and hunting because it is a warhorse and does not shy away easily. you can also have the same horse for free if you steal it from mr.wrobel's stable when collecting strauss's debt.

while capturing the white arabian is a really enjoyable, and amazing experience i did it every time i started a new game, you can get the literally best horse early as well the black arabian, wich is only awailable for purchase at the epiloge with john. you can head to saint denies, hang around the big building, near the clothing shop, at night, after 6pm, and you can witness a robbery, where a young man try to rob a pair of wealthy person. if you get rid of the robber shoot him or so.. you get a bonus good karma, and you can snitch his horse, near the carriage, wich is a black arabian, for free. you don't even have to tame it, buy it, or break it! also you can loot it's saddle bag for extra trinkets it is important in rdr 2 to get your dream horse early, imo, soo... yeah. i loved this little thing, it felt like a side mission, just like getting the white arabian from them mountains.

my guess for the final one is he was the antagonist, yes, but not the bad guy in the situation. milton had been simply doing his job the entire time and gave the gang countless chances to leave unscathed before he began hunting them down. milton probably felt remorse for arthur. considering milton was assigned the van der line case, he more than likely had to learn everything about the gang and its members, so he would know a lot about arthur and his upbringing. he probably felt sympathetic for him because he was forced into that type of life with no other choice. also, he is a firm believer in the law and would probably rather have him given a fair trial than a frontier type of justice. if he did shoot him, it'd show he is no more of an animalmonster than the van der line gang is.

milton is an interesting case. hes the first time the gang realizes there can be civil resolutions and not the wild west showdowns they are used to. he approaches them a few times offering dutchs head in exchange for the freedom of the gang and is met with hostility and in some cases fatal shootings. ive been thinking about this lately but i think the reason edgar decided to betray john in rdr1 is because he watched his boss try to do things in a civil manner and each time it never worked. he realized through the death of his boss milton that these are outlaws through and through and that the van der linde gang can not be bartered with so he used john then disposed of him once john did the heavy lifting.
i never noticed bill's devastated face when he had to choose between dutch and arthur. that and javier lifting his gun explains why they chose to not chase down arthur and john.

chapter 6 was so depressing. nothing made sense anymore, seeing arthur deteriorating broke my heart. i didn't feel like doing any challenge anymore or going hunting. i have spent the least amount of time in beaver hollow camp. i am so glad they had some uplifting missions that brought a little joy, like the widow charlotte, helping people.

i honestly just thought that milton didnt shoot arthur in the face because he couldnt. the hammer of the schofield isnt cocked that entire altercation, and the revolver is a single action. also, the by time it looked like the gun was pointed at arthurs face it looked like arthur had one hand on miltons gun and the other on his handwrist, stopping the hammer from being pulled back.

the entire beaver creek arc is one of the most gut wrenching arcs ive ever experienced in a video game. it was jarring, seeing stern strong stoic arthur morgan begin to get sick outside of cutscenes. it was a genius way they implemented it. i went in blind in 2018, had no clue about the tb, all i knew was that arthur wasnt in rdr 1. chapter 45 i began to notice my cores draining faster, and hed start coughing a little bit here and there. then in chapter 6, seeing big badass arthur run out of stamina while hunting, or wheezing duringafter running, or seeing him randomly coughing into his hand and there being blood on it, was jarring. let alone the spiritual aspect of it all, arthur being afraid of whats to come, thinking about his entire life of sin, wanting to help those he thinks he can help. and seeing the entire thing come crumbling down when just a little while before the gang was celebrating and throwing a party. the real tragedy is the fact that nearly everyone except a pretty injured john who would've had arthurs back and likely backed him up 100 when he blew the lid off the whole operation were either dead hosea, lenny, kieran, sean, grimshaw, was just killed. or gonesent away by arthurescaped on their own karen, pearson, marybeth, sadie, tilly, charles, abigail, the reverend, uncle
should i just sneak on now? god damnit.

hate when people try making milton look better than what he actually was...he shot hosea while he was unarmed in cold blood in front of the saint denis bank. he also bragged about one of the callender boys dying a slow death when he got to him. he was killing people in a frontier manner. people make milton out to be some fair man. he was edgar ross mentor who turned out to be even more of a piece of shit than him. agent milton was a lowdown mf. he only gave chances because he knew how dangerous the van der linde gang was. him and one other guy walked into their camp to manipulate dutch into giving himself up maybe to disband their most influential memberleader so it would be easier to pick off the rest with dutch being out of the picture. he knew dutch was smart and dangerous, articulate and persuasive. if he could take that from them he would have returned the way ross did and murdered everybody when they were vulnerable. he was playing chess with the gang and only conquered because dutch went batshit and everybody split with each other. that's what he wanted all along which is probably why he had micah in dutch ear to do exactly that. as a whole the gang was untouchable to an extent but during panick, separation and feelings of betrayal it was the checkmate. in the end everybody got smoked even him. milton was just as grimey as dutch. they were both silver tongued with devious behavior they just operated on opposite sides of the law. when i played this game for the first time i paid attention to every single detail down to the smallest. if you pay attention you can really understand how everything panned out, who had a shady character, who's intentions were right or wrong and what was actually going on. i recognized the bullshit early on the game with several characters. milton and dutch were a reflection of each other. that's why the battle was harder and more intense than the o'driscolls. even arthur said he didn't care about them anymore after seeing colm swing because there was a bigger threat on the rise and with the deterioration of the gang he knew it was a matter of time before they all got wiped out finally. dutch let that happen by not knowing what to believe anymore, losing his faith and betraying his most loyal and strongest members. micah did that for milton to survive and escape with money. if john didn't come to kill him he probably would have killed dutch and took the money anyway. milton found a weak spot in the gang micah because the gang relied on loyalty which obviously micah didn't appreciate as much as the rest. milton found his diamond in the rough to finally take the gang down. milton was not a good person or fair.

dear brad ive been watching your channel since the very first day. im a disabled old dude in australia with a wife and a beagle. thats it. i dont get out much bc of my disabilities which are numerous. i suffer from horrible depression and anxiety some day i can barely get out of bed even. i just wanted to say thank you . when i watch your vids it helps me and as pathetic as it sounds i pretend im sitting there with you as your mate just goofing off and having a good time and stuff. it makes me feel like i have friends who give a crap about me. it helps my loneliness and hopelessness. i just wanted you to know that what you do isnt just about playing games but it actually helps miserable losers like me. what you do helps millions im sure. like i have said ive been with you from the beginning and even tho youve never acknowledged me its okay. ill continue to watch you and play along with your videos im also,really glad things ar going well with yoir daughter and wife and chubs. i know he got sick awhile back and i hope he lives a very long happy life. i love it when you tell us to hold on in the middle of talking to us .as if we have a choice ! crack me up. god bless you sir. what you do makes a difference. cheers from australia. carl
